text: Good morning guys how are we all doing?
So today we're going to do things a little bit different from yesterday
yesterday we talked about Tallinn's history
and today we're going to find our whats happening in the modern times
Since the fall of communism, Tallinn has gone through a lot of changes
it is one of the most dynamic cities on the Baltic
and so we're going to start off by going to Kalamaja, it's like the up and coming neighborhood, the hipster place
and we're going to start off with some breakfast
let's go
Gotta have a good breakfast, the key to starting any day
ya Cafe Boheem was the first coffee shop to be opened in Kalamaja
by all accounts back in the day, it was not the nicest neighborhood to live in
but since 2008, when this restaurant and coffee shop opened, kind of started like a chain reaction
and the neighborhood has become one of the hipper, more desirable places to live here in Tallinn
Guys so Lina's going to show us the neighborhood of Kalamaja
what's the plan for today?
the plan is to take the bikes, cycle around, see some of the sites, some of the cooler places this area has to offer
I'm giving you kind of an overview of what this place has been and what it maybe will be one day as well
awesome, let's go
so a bit about this neighborhood this was originally a fishing village
that's where the name comes from
but in the 1870's Estonia, Tallinn was linked to St. Petersburg by train
the Tsars started industrialization here so there's a lot of factories
and they needed housing for the factory workers, that's why these houses were built
they were made from wood which was the cheapest material because Estonia's covered in forests
so there's a new sort of creative class moving in here and giving a bunch of new energy to the neighborhood
so we're going to hop on some bikes and go check it out
ok, our steeds for the day
hoped on some bicycles and we're headed to the Volta Factory
which used to make electric generators and is now kind of like a cool ruin thing, so we're going to cycle over there and take a look
we're in the Volta Factory area
Here in Soviet times it produced electric generators
Beginning of the 90's when Estonia becomes independent again, the eastern market collapses,
no one in the west wants our stuff and areas like this become subject to metal theft
This is freaky
I don't know if this is a good idea but there is a ladder up to the next level
and
time to take it to the next level
let's climb it
wow....this is cool
I don't know how safe it is up here but it's all made from limestone so....it's got to be sturdy right?
This is..pretty intense i'm not going to lie
It's crazy to see these places that, you know, once were vibrant, thriving factories
just kind of left as rubble and ruin
It's wild to think that when economies shit, when things change, that buildings like this are left behind
until anyone can figure out what to do with them, they kind of just sit here unused
but I can picture this in a decade being artists lofts with cafe's, restaurants, craft beer bar
this is definitely the cafe right here
but until then, it's just going to sit here unused
but it gives you some insight on how neighborhoods like this go through different transformations
and how modern Estonia is finding new ways to use these places
Right now we're on the Culture Kilometer
it's a bike path, walkway, built when Tallinn was the cultural capital of the EU in 2011
it's not actually a kilometer it's 2.2 kilometers but who's counting?
just the Vagabrothers
so from here we're going to a restaurant called Klaus, it's not so far, it's pretty "close"

Telliskivi is essentially a hub of entrepreneurs and small businesses, restaurants, bars, designers
that sprouted up in the old factory so it's kind of like the final stage of the abandoned factory we saw
it's been renovated and it really is like a city, there's a lot of things going on

physically it's the center of new culture as we call it
and it's a former industrial building that is now transformed into offices, bars, cafes, theaters, art exhibitions spaces
and lots of festival ground
this is the second abandoned building that we've been in today
but I think this one speaks really to the creativity, industriousness, and resourcefulness of the Estonian people
standing here and seeing the creativity that's coming out of this place, is just, shows what people can do with freedom

it's only one of many such factories here  in Tallinn

and just make this new really innovative, dynamic city here on the Baltic
